title: 108_hr2093
content: The Act may be cited as the "Old Man of the Mountain Commemorative Coin Act". It includes findings related to the subject matter. The Congress finds that the Old Man of the Mountain, a symbol of New Hampshire's independence and traditions, stood for 10,000 years before collapsing from a granite cliff on Cannon Mountain. The Old Man of the Mountain, a symbol of New Hampshire, collapsed in 2003, leading to efforts to commemorate its legacy with a commemorative coin to fund a suitable memorial. The text chunk is about the specifications of a commemorative coin. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items under the Act. According to title 31, United States Code, all coins minted under this Act are considered numismatic items. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of the Old Man of the Mountain, with inscriptions including the value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". Numismatic design features may include reverse proofing or raised lettering on the edge of the coin. The design for the coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Old Man of the Mountain Revitalization Fund, Inc., and reviewed by the Citizens Coin Advisory Committee. The design may include unique numismatic features like raised lettering on the edge of the coin. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility starting August 28, 2005, with minting authority ending on December 31, 2006. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and design/issuance costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. Sales of coins minted under this Act will include a surcharge of $35 per $5 coin and $10 per $1 coin. Surcharges received will be promptly paid to the Old Man of the Mountain Revitalization Fund, Inc. for its objects and purposes. The Fund will be audited as per the requirements of title 31, United States Code.
